results.title: WCSC
results.brief_description:
Tune in as Jerry and Bruce commentate the sports event of the millennium! Rushkov versus Javichenko. Be sure to experience the giddying highs of Friday night WCSC live at Viagro Stadium.
Animated work. Includes animated nudity. Voices - Trent Baker, Simon Philamon. Written, directed and animated by Michael Hill.

results.title: Tree of us
results.creator_credit: Vilakone Phachanthavong and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
Vilakone has created powerful graphics in this animated work about the family of the future through the use of a predominantly red background, with black and white hand-drawn images. No dialogue.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.

Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.

results.title: Under the influence
results.creator_credit: Fletcher Cheng and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
One wrong decision and your life can turn into hell. An intriguing computer animated moral tale of alcohol and addiction with a great soundtrack - music by Fletcher Cheng. No dialogue.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2004.

results.title: City of chromatic dissolution
results.brief_description:
Arthur and Corinne Cantrill used footage of Melbourne’s cityscapes and buildings from the mid 1980s to create this evocative piece on movement, colour and the city. The various parts of inner city Melbourne were originally shot on black and white negative in three colour separation, then printed on Eastmancolor film. The results are static shots of the city, where the movement of people and vehicles have a quality that is colour saturated and ghostly. This is complemented with a sountrack both urban and discordant in tone.
This is one of a series of films made by the Cantrills that experiment with dramatic distortions of colour through three-colour separation processes. The original inspiration for this project (as the filmmakers report in the final edition of Cantrills Filmnotes) came back in the mid-1970s when Kodak stopped making the Cantrills’ preferred 16mm reversal colour film stocks.

The results are static shots of the city, where the movement of people and vehicles have a quality that is colour saturated and ghostly. The original inspiration for this project (as the filmmakers report in the final edition of Cantrills Filmnotes) came back in the mid-1970s when Kodak stopped making the Cantrills’ preferred 16mm reversal colour film stocks.

results.title: Warriors and dancers
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Narjiic Day-Burns
results.brief_description:
Narjiic’s passion for music and dance began in Year 10 when he was asked to perform for NAIDOC Week. From there he joined various dance groups performing all over Victoria including his home town Echuca, finally enrolling at Swinburne. Today he blends a fusion of traditional dance with hip-hop as a way of expressing his thoughts and emotions. Dance has become a part of his life.
Music by Fonetik.

results.title: Violence is Violence
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.brief_description: A report on the concerns over the private toll road which was built at the expense of over 2 hectares of public parkland in inner Sydney. Hundreds of Sydney residents take over the streets to protest car-dominated public space and offer a vision of urban sustainability. Their celebration is met with a brutal police response. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
results.creator_credit_for_label: SKA TV, Campbell Manderson and Pip Starr
results.description: A report on the concerns over the private toll road which was built at the expense of over 2 hectares of public parkland in inner Sydney. Hundreds of Sydney residents take over the streets to protest car-dominated public space and offer a vision of urban sustainability. Their celebration is met with a brutal police response. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
